Comments_Questions: How clearly did the instructor define the topic of study
How clearly did the instructor outline the expectation for the course, classroom activity and homework
How well were individual class sessions prepared and presented
How well did lectures fit within the boundaries of the course
How available was the instructor for help outside the classroom
How useful were assignments in furthering an understanding of the topic
If tests were given, how fairly did they measure knowledge gained?
How useful was this course in preparing you for production work
How would you evaluate the instructor's knowledge of the material
Please offer additional comments on such topics as: what worked best about the course, suggested improvements, class materials, etc.
Comments_List: He literally wrote the book on the subject...
The topic was defined extremely well.
Followed the syllabus and had clear expectations
Alan does a great job of telling us up front what we are going to be learning, and then sticking to that plan.

Alan is truly a teacher and conveys information in a number of ways that allow for a variety of learning styles - example's: PowerPoint's and printed material, hands on examples and physical demonstrations.
Alan is great at referring to the book or the handouts, and by presenting clear lessons in the class, the students are able to keep track of where they are headed in the lesson.

While I do not fault the instructor for this there were issues with the projector in the classroom for the majority of the semester, usually it would work after a fashion but time was wasted and for a class that was largely reliant on projected presentations it was a necessity that it be working.
Always on topic.
lessons were well timed and would rarely go outside the bounds of class.
Good balance to reinforce understanding of subject matter without the overburdening of an already too heavy schedule. Better balance than most YSD courses.

The workload was great, the lessons gave us basic knowledge up front, then would level up as we got more and more sophisticated in the knowledge.  Alan wisely teaches this way, as I feel it gives us the chance to understand where we are headed while understanding how we got there.
There was just the right amount of work added to help reinforce the lectures.
This class probably could have more assignments outside of class time. As it is grades are based primarily on the three exams given through the semester.
I hate to admit it, but there could have been more homework. However, having an assignment every two weeks was an excellent pace.

More available than my schedule was to utilize the resource. The production assignment load alone would be too much, adding work study to that time means minimal to no time to capitalize on the depth I'd like to for this course.
either via email or his desk in B1, Alan was always available.
I did not engage him for help outside of class.
They did that.
extremely useful, they were appropriately difficult for the subject matter.

There was a lot of new information for me. The homework allowed me to practice what I saw in class. I waited too long for the last homework and in turn had a much harder time with that material. The assignments did an excellent job reinforcing the concepts.

The examples done in class were directly helpful to the homework and understanding of the topic. It would be more helpful to write the units for numbers in an equation at the beginning of a problem and all the way through. When referring back to my notes, it was difficult to identify where some numbers came from.
Being open book the tests do mirror how one would apply this work to an actual problem in the field more closely than if it were closed notes.
good, practical tests of how these lessons actually apply to our work.

The tests were good examples of what you would actually be expected to look for in real life situations. The final test was a bit more difficult to wrap my head around, but there was just many different parts to think about and many options.
Good, if this type of production work becomes part of my future.
extremely useful, as the production work that came up for me was immediately informed by the lessons of this class.
I haven't used this in production work yet but feel confident it will be very helpful.
I will likely need more help with hardware sourcing but otherwise it is an incredibly helpful course.
He wrote the book on this topic.
this is a laughable question.  It's Alan Hendrickson.
Not all teachers here are here because of their ability, training, or experience in teaching. Alan is a teacher and I personally really appreciate that quality in a teacher.

I feel that the linear and circular motion sections were really clear, but the motor and gear selection were less so. 
I feel that there were a lot of assumptions about knowledge built into the class that should be addressed for someone who has never built or installed a machine before. 
We never did an example of the selecting a motor in class and I wish we had.
given how confusing the subject matter could be, it was great to have sample homework and test questions that provided examples that could be followed to help with the understanding.

When transitioning from the "theory/fundamentals" units to the tangible unit on power transmission and motor selection/winch design, we started right away with types of gears. A day where we see a working deck winch (as an example) and go over all of the components and how they interact would have been very helpful. I have little hands on experience with stage machinery or motors in general, so in effect I was learning pieces and "assembling" them in my mind at the very end of the course. Personally, I find it easier to learn these types of things when presented with a fully sketched out ending of what we're looking for, and then deconstructing/examining the pieces/components. I am easily confused and lost without a strong sense of context.

After the class I feel automation has been somewhat demystified, which is great. I still think I will have a lot of work to become adequate at it, but I feel like that is more achievable. Learning about what forces are looked at with different effects really helps to focus conversations around automation in the future.
